occurrences.line_text: For first it was to thee reprochfull blame,
And passed forth, to follow his first enterprise.
On which the first, whose force her first doth bring,
On which the first, whose force her first doth bring,
To haue supplyde the first, and paide the vsury.
In prime of youthly yeares, when first the flowre
On his first quest, in which did him betide
But first it falleth me by course to tell
When first the gentle Squire at variaunce fell
And first they spoile her of her iewels deare,
He first her hands beginneth to vnbind,
Him first from court he to the citties coursed,
The time was once, in my first prime of yeares,
And first him greeting, thus vnto him spake;
The first of them hight mylde Euphrosyne,
With heauenly gifts from heuen first enraced?
To whome in sort, as he at first begonne,
Which Coridon first hearing, ran in hast
But first of all, their captiues they doe kill,
To greet him first, but askt were where the rest;
First all the captiues, which they here had hent,
Still slew the formost, that came first to hand,
This gentle knight, from sewing his first quest,
Of his first quest, which he had long forlore;
But first, ere I doe his aduentures tell,
Sometime a fowle, sometime a fish in lake,
The fish that once was caught, new bait will hardly bite.
To which nor fish nor fowle did once approch,
The dreadfull Fish, that hath deseru'd the name
Transform'd to fish, for their bold surquedry,
Her garments gay with scales of fish, that all did fill.
Of his owne fish vnto their festiuall,
Both thirty sorts of fish, and thirty sundry streames.
Could swim like to a fish, whiles he his backe bestrad.
But vsd to fish for fooles on the dry shore,
With which he seldome fished at the brooke,
In which there slept a fisher old and pore,
But all the while the fisher did securely sleepe.
At last some fisher barke doth neare behold,
Finding in it fit ports for fishers trade,
For being fled into the fishers bote,
And comming to that Fishers wandring bote,
And out of that same fishers filthy nest
Great whirlpooles, which all fishes make to flee,
The rest of other fishes drawen weare,
And let their temed fishes softly swim
And all the fruitfull spawne of fishes hew
That of a fishes shell was wrought with rare delight.
Ten thousand fishes play, and decke his pleasant streame.
The birds to catch, or fishes to beguyle:
The pleasant Boyne, the fishy fruitfull Ban,
More light then Culuer in the Faulcons fist.
Vpon her fist the bird, which shonneth vew,
Blindfold he was, and in his cruell fist
Out of her fist the wicked weapon caught:
Him with his fist vnwares on th'head he strooke,
And bruze with clownish fistes his manly face:
In drowsie fit he findes: of nothing he takes keepe.
A fit false dreame, that can delude the sleepers sent.
Cast a blacke stole, most like to seeme for Vna fit.
That keepes thy body from the bitter fit;
A girlond for her dainty forehead fit,
Faire Vna framed words and count'nance fit:
But when the furious fit was ouerpast,
Whom broad awake she finds, in troublous fit,
And him amoues with speaches seeming fit:
Such fearefull fit assaid her trembling hart,
To dally thus with death, is no fit toy,
With dying fit, that downe she fell for paine.
Which like a feuer fit through all his body swelt.
And Pupill fit for such a Tutours hand.
What franticke fit (quoth he) hath thus distraught
Faire Goddesse lay that furious fit aside,
That auncient Lord gan fit occasion finde,
His owne two hands, for such a turne most fit,
Th'enchaunter finding fit for his intents,
Fit to inflame faire Lady with loues rage,
Fit mate for such a mincing mineon,
Trompart fit man for Braggadocchio,
The wood is fit for beasts, the court is fit for thee.
The wood is fit for beasts, the court is fit for thee.
But when the franticke fit inflamd his spright,
Or faultie thoughts continewd, as was fit;
On which was drawen faire, in colours fit,
Trees, braunches, birds, and songs were framed fit,
Her merry fit she freshly gan to reare,
Perdie, then is it fit for me (said he)
Those be the riches fit for an aduent'rous knight.
More fit amongst blacke fiendes, then men to haue his place.
Fit to adorne the dead, and decke the drery toombe.
And all his senses were with deadly fit opprest.
Whiles deadly fit thy pupill doth dismay;
Finding in it fit ports for fishers trade,
In all that seemed fit for kingly seed:
Her mighty charmes, her furious louing fit,
Not fit for speedy pace, or manly exercize.
And antique praises vnto present persons fit.
Which her assayd with many a feruent fit,
Till she mote winne fit time for her desire,
And striuing, fit to make, I feare do marre:
As if she had a feuer fit, did quake,
What vncouth fit (said she) what euill plight
Their fit disports with faire delight doe chose,
Into her former fit; for why, no powre
Th'vneuen number for this businesse is most fit.
But that sweet fit, that doth true beautie loue,
Which suddein fit, and halfe extatick stoure
Daughter, I deeme that counsell aye most fit,
It fortuned (so time their turne did fit)
Both speare & shield of great powre, for her purpose fit.
Soone as she vp out of her deadly fit
Ministreth matter fit, which tempred right
Some fit for reasonable soules t'indew,
But past awhile, when she fit season saw
And louely face, made fit for to deceiue
Fit song of Angels caroled to bee;
Abounded, being glad of so fit tyde
Fruitfull of all things fit for liuing foode,
A fit occasion for his turne to find:
Darke was the Euening, fit for louers stealth,
Which when she heard, and saw the ghastly fit,
Fit medcine to his griefe, and spake thus courtesly.
Long were to tell each other louely fit,
Yclad in costly garments, fit for tragicke Stage.
She cast to vse, both fit for hard emprize;
The deare compassion of whose bitter fit
To them appear'd, with shield and armour fit;
To be most fit to trouble noble knights,
The outrage of his furious fit relented.
And finding now fit opportunity
But euermore, when she fit time could fynd,
But finding no fit seat, the lifelesse corse it left.
With oaken leaues attrapt, that seemed fit
For he me seemes most fit the faire to serue,
And she most fit his seruice doth deserue,
Fit time t'awaite auenged for to bee.
Did find it fit, withouten breach or let.
Yet nathemore would it her bodie fit;
Yet not fit place he thought it there to stay,
Right fit to rend the food, on which he fared.
To be spectators of this vncouth fit,
Fit time for him thence to depart it found,
A leman fit for such a louer deare.
And framed speaches fit for his behoofe,
And finding there fit solitary place
Who wondring much at that so sodaine fit,
Fresh shadowes, fit to shroud from sunny ray;
Whom seeing fit, and with no crime defilde,
Were worke fit for an Herauld, not for me:
With diuers fortune fit for such a game,
But some fayre Franion, fit for such a fere,
Yet it to none of all their loynes would fit,
Fit for such Ladies and such louely knights:
All sodainely enflam'd with furious fit,
And beare with you both wine and iuncates fit,
In stead of Curiets and bases fit for fight.
But drew him on with hope, fit leasure to awayt.
Yet to awayt fit time she weened best,
And with faire words, fit for the time and place,
But none she found so fit to serue that turne,
Such was this Ladies fit, in her loues fond accusing.
Yet not, as women wont in dolefull fit,
As a mad bytch, when as the franticke fit
Marcht with that mayd, fit matter for another song.
Not fit mongst men, that doe with reason mell,
Fit for Adicia, there to build her wicked bowre.
Fit to catch hold of all that he could weld,
Them entertayn'd, fit for their dignities,
To doe, what euer he thought good or fit.
For stil when fit occasion did betyde,
Most squalid garments, fit for such a day,
Yet when as fit aduantage he did spy,
Meat fit for such a monsters monsterous dyeat.
With whom those graces did so goodly fit:
Therefore, good Sir, sith now occasion fit
So hauing both found fit occasion,
The pensiue fit of her melancholie;
But first him seemed fit, that wounded Knight
Of lodging fit for any errant Knight,
He gan in mind conceiue a fit reliefe
Being now soft and fit them to embrace;
As to them seemed fit time to entertaine.
Finde harbour fit to comfort her great neede.
Somewhile with merry purpose fit to please,
He to that point fit speaches gan to frame,
Vntill fit time and place he mote espy,
With shepheards hooke in hand, and fit attyre,
With such queint vsage, fit for Queenes and Kings,
That Colin Clout should pipe as one most fit;
And to the waters fall tuning their accents fit.
Long time, as fit occasion forth them led;
Fit to keepe sheepe, vnfit for loues content:
In greene vine leaues he was right fitly clad;
In his big base them fitly answered,
To her this song most fitly is addrest,
So fitly now here commeth next in place,
That for another Canto will more fitly fall.
So many furies and sharpe fits did haunt,
He is conuaide, but how or where, here fits not tell.
Soone into other fits he was transmewed,
And furious fits at earst quite weren quaild:
And with sharpe fits thy tender hart oppresseth sore.
And sweet loue gentle fits emongst them throwes,
But when she had with such vnquiet fits
As one for knightly giusts and fierce encounters fitt.
So none should be out shut, sith all of loues were fitted.
And now himselfe he fitted had right well,
Who round about her tender wast it fitted well.
Proffer thy giftes, and fitter seruaunts entertaine.
Not with such forged showes, as fitter beene
And fittest for to forge true-seeming lyes;
And round about in fittest steades did place,
Him such, as fittest she for loue could find,
Whom so she fittest finds to serue her lust,
Found it the fittest soyle for their abode,
One prison fittest is to hold vs two:
Whom she thought fittest for that businesse,
The Blatant Beast the fittest meanes they found,
But fittest is, that all contented rest
At length when they occasion fittest found,
To whom I thus, Nay but it fitteth best,
And fitteth most for noble swayne to know,
And fitting gestures to her purpose frame;
And for her humour fitting purpose faine,
On which they lowly sit, and fitting purpose frame.
With spightfull speaches, fitting with her well;
What vertue is so fitting for a knight,
Fiue ioynts thereof he hewd, and but the stump him left.
Fiue sonnes he left begotten of one wife,
Then all the sonnes of these fiue brethren raynd
The other fiue, fiue sundry wayes he set,
The other fiue, fiue sundry wayes he set,
Against the fiue great Bulwarkes of that pile,
There those fiue sisters had continuall trade,
Fiue dayes there be, since he (they say) was slaine,
Of Alexander, and his Princes fiue,
Had left her now but fiue of all that brood:
In which a rustie knife fast fixed stood,
The other foot, fast fixed on his shield,
With doubtfull eyes fast fixed on his guest;
Thereat with staring eyes fixed askaunce,
Were fixed at his backe, to cut his ayerie wayes.
With her false eyes fast fixed in his sight,
Though strange beginning had, yet fixed is
And euer firmely fixed did abide
And with pale eyes fast fixed on the rest,
Yet nothing could my fixed mind remoue,
For stedfast still her eyes did fixed rest,
Ne ought he did, but with fast fixed eies
Being fast fixed in her wounded spright,
Yet in my truthes assurance I rest fixed fast.
The eyes of all, which thereon fixed beene;
His poysnous point deepe fixed in his hart
These marchants fixed eyes did so amaze,
But firme is fixt, and sendeth light from farre
To looken backe; his eyes be fixt before.
Was firmest fixt in mine extremest case,
Ireland subdewd, and therein fixt his throne,
The worlds foundations from his centre fixt;
And euermore on daunger fixt his eye,
Mine eye was fixt, for feare of her offence:
But firmely fixt they were, with dint of sword,
That their broad flaggie finnes no fome did reare,
His flaggy wings when forth he did display,
He flyes about, and with his flaggy wings
Amongst the flags and couert round about.
And layd on load with his huge yron flaile,
But when at them he with his flaile gan lay,
He with his yron flaile amongst them thondred,
With his rude yron flaile, they gan to flie,
He ioynted it, and mard the swinging of her flaile.
With his huge flaile began to lay about;
Would her haue chastiz'd with his yron flaile,
A flake of fire, that flashing in his beard,
Flasht through her face, as it had been a flake
Their fluttring arrowes, thicke as flakes of snow,
By casting secret flakes of lustfull fire
That flakes of fire, bright as the sunny ray,
Who in his hand an yron flale did hould,
And with his iron flale at it let flie,
Who with few sowces of his yron flale,
He with his yron flale did thresh so thin,
He should his flale to finall execution bend.
So flam'd his eyne with rage and rancorous yre:
Therein gaue light, and flam'd continually:
And flam'd with zeale of vengeance inwardly,
And quench the flame of furious despight,
And euery head with fyrie tongue did flame,
The scorching flame sore swinged all his face,
In her faire eyes two liuing lamps did flame,
But added flame vnto his former fire,
But th'other was Impatience, arm'd with raging flame.
Yt seemd th'enchaunted flame, which did CreÃ¼sa wed.
But as a coale to kindle fleshly flame,
My raging smart, ne ought my flame relent,
Ne slake the furie of her cruell flame,
Which shall breake forth into bright burning flame,
Closely the wicked flame his bowels brent,
And kindled heat, that soone in flame forth brust:
To flame the gates, and hearing them to call
Shewing desire her inward flame to slake:
Gathred the Troian reliques sau'd from flame,
And all men busie to suppresse the flame,
Assayld the flame, the which eftsoones gaue place,
So like, that all the walles did seeme to flame.
And flame with gold, but the white fomy creame,
She found: for now that fained dreadfull flame,
Ne in their frosen hearts feele kindly flame:
Whose fire were better turn'd to other flame;
And what he was, whose eyes did flame with fire;
And quenched is with Cupids greater flame:
And odours rising from the altars flame.
My children and my people, burnt in flame;
And flame forth honour in thy noble brest:
To Calepine, his heart did inly flame
So easie was to quench his flamed mind
As raging flames who striueth to suppresse.
And scorching flames of fierce Orions hound,
And hurle not flashing flames vpon that Paynim bold?
Enrold in flames, and smouldring dreriment,
Which troubled once, into huge flames will grow,
But told it flames, and hidden it does glow,
Those creeping flames by reason to subdew,
Send forth their flames farre off to euery shyre,
That flames of fire he threw forth fro[m] his large nosethrill.
Huge flames, that dimmed all the heauens light,
Doth belch out flames, and rockes in peeces broke,
Did rend the ratling skyes with flames of fouldring heat.
He hath a sword, that flames like burning brond.
Burning in flames, yet no flames can I see,
Burning in flames, yet no flames can I see,
These flames, these flames (he cryde) do me torment.
These flames, these flames (he cryde) do me torment.
What flames (quoth he) when I thee present see,
Harrow, the flames, which me consume (said hee)
His greedy flames, and kindled life-deuouring fire.
That it in flames of Aetna wrought apart,
Nourish the flames, which they are warm'd vpon,
It now deuoures with flames and scorching heat,
With breathed flames, like to a furnace red,
(Said he,) out of the flames for safegard fled,
The Troiane flames, and reach to heauens hight
To quench the flames, which she had tyn'd before,
Soone as the cruell flames yslaked were,
Out of the flames, which he had quencht whylere
So to her yold the flames, and did their force reuolt,
And bad the stubborne flames to yield him way:
That soone they life conceiu'd, & forth in flames did fly.
Those dreadfull flames she also found delayd,
Misdeeming sure that her those flames did burne;
The furious flames of malice to asswage.
With feruent flames, and loued out of measure:
Into outragious flames vnwares did grow,
Both flames and tempest: with which growen great,
And raging flames, that many foes shall reare,
And feruour of his flames somewhat adaw:
And inly burnt with flames most raging whot,
And flaming mouthes of steedes vnwonted wilde
The flaming corage of that Faery knight,
His suddein eye, flaming with wrathfull fyre,
And lilled forth his bloudie flaming tong:
From flaming mouth bright sparkles fierie red,
And threatned all his heads like flaming brands.
Ne reard aboue the earth his flaming creast,
Out of the East, with flaming lockes bedight,
His flaming head did hasten for to steepe,
A flaming fire in midst of bloudy field,
With that he drew his flaming sword, and strooke
Now brought to him a flaming fire brond,
Yet nought can quench mine inly flaming syde,
In flaming Phlegeton does not so felly roste.
More whot, then Aetn', or flaming Mongiball:
Now seeming flaming whot, now stony cold.
His hearie beames, and flaming lockes dispred,
And with her flaming sword about her layd,
To seeke young men, to quench her flaming thurst,
To dry them selues by Vulcanes flaming light,
A flaming fire, ymixt with smouldry smoke,
His flaming furie sought to haue assuaged
Shooting forth farre away two flaming streames,
All flaming with their sacrifices fire,
And both adorn'd with lampes of flaming light,
Of flaming, and her selfe in great perplexity.
So long as in his steedes the flaming breath did last.
And fenst himselfe about with many a flaming brand.
All flaming with reuenge and furious despight.
Aboue the earth vpreard his flaming head,
With flaming sword in hand his terror more to breed.
He smote his courser in the trembling flancke,
Which mote the feebled Britons strongly flancke
And flancked both the bridges sides along,
Right in the flanke him strooke with deadly dreare,
Towardes him runs, and with rude flaring lockes
And fire did flash, like lightning after thunder,
And from her eies did flash out fiery light,
Like lightening flash, that hath the gazer burned,
And through her eyes like sudden lightning flashed,
No foote to foe. The flashing fier flies
While flashing beames do daze his feeble eyen,
With flashing thunderbolt ywounded sore:
And hurle not flashing flames vpon that Paynim bold?
At flashing beames of that sunshiny shield,
He did receiue, whiles flashing fire about him shone.
A flake of fire, that flashing in his beard,
With foule enfouldred smoake and flashing fire,
The flashing bloud with blushing did inflame,
And all the world with flashing fier brent;
Of flashing fire, and heare the ordenance thonder,
Out of her steely armes were flashing seene,
As when the flashing Leuin haps to light
But with his raging armes he rudely flasht,
Flasht through her face, as it had been a flake
That from the same the fierie sparkles flasht,
The woodborne people fall before her flat,
Where falling flat, great humblesse he did make,
And ayme at him, fell flat to ground for feare,
To seize vpon his foe flat lying on the marle.
Yet flat refusd to haue a do with mee,
But euermore she him refused flat,
When forward we should fare, he flat refused
Fell flat to ground, ne word vnto him sayd,
Tho with her sword on him she flatling strooke,
For flatly he of entrance was refusd,
Yet whether thwart or flatly it did lyte,
And both from rocks and flats it selfe could wisely saue.
And when her listed, she could fawne and flatter;
Some by close shouldring, some by flatteree;
Despysde, and all the fawning of the flatterer.
Bad counsels, prayses, and false flatteries.
With flattering words he sweetly wooed her,
His idle humour with fine flattery,
For he loathd leasing, and base flattery,
So when he saw his flatt'ring arts to fayle,
And with faire countenance and flattring stile,
Through his faire daughters face, & flattring word;
From that first flaw him selfe right well defended.
That he thereon should spin both flax and tow;
Haue turn'd himselfe, he with his yron flayle
But chiefly Talus with his yron flayle,
Lookt for her knight, who far away was fled,
But from him fled away with all her powre;
And fled away: for neuer in that land
Full fast she fled, ne euer lookt behynd,
Fled farre away, of that proud Paynim sore afrayd.
But leauing all behind her, fled away:
Fled to the wastfull wildernesse apace,
Still as he fled, his eye was backward cast,
Fled fast away, halfe dead with dying feare:
Would faine haue fled, ne durst approchen neare,
The cloudes before him fled for terrour great,
Some feard, and fled; some feard and well it faynd;
And now is fled; foule shame him follow, where he went.
As Hind from her, so she fled from her enimy.
Both fled attonce, ne euer backe returned eie.
As through the flouring forrest rash she fled,
So turned her about, and fled away apace.
She fled away with ghastly dreriment,
Eftsoones he fled away, and might no where be seene.
Fled fast away, to tell his funerall
That art thus foully fled from famous enemie?
The whiles false Archimarge and Atin fled apace.
A while they fled, but soone returnd againe
Yet in the chace was slaine of them, that fled:
By this the sonnes of Constantine, which fled,
That how the time was fled, they quite forgate,
And fast the land behind them fled away.
Which fled a sunder, and him fell before,
His light-foot beast, fled fast away for feare:
For as the winged wind his Tigre fled,
Apace he shot, and yet he fled apace,
Yet nathemore forth fled his groning spright,
Fled all away for feare of fowler shame.
Which fled so fast, that nothing mote him hold,
Still as she fled, her eye she backward threw,
Who from them fled, as light-foot hare from vew
Was fled afore, affraid of him, as feend of hell.
That fearefull Ladie fled from him, that ment
That fast she from him fled, no lesse affrayd,
But that fierce foster, which late fled away,
Out of her fleshly ferme fled to the place of paine.
With that he would haue fled into the wood;
She fled into the wildernesse a space,
Was from her fled, as flit as ayerie Doue,
(So from her often he had fled away,
Who in his frowardnesse from her was fled;
Which fled so fast from that same foster stearne,
And from Prince Arthur fled with wings of idle feare.
So fled faire Florimell from her vaine feare,
Nor wearinesse to slacke her hast, but fled
Not halfe so fast the wicked Myrrha fled
Fled fearefull Daphne on th'ï¿½gï¿½an strond,
As Florimell fled from that Monster yond,
But trembled like a lambe, fled from the pray,
Had she not fled into a secret mew,
But left his loue to losse, and fled himselfe apace.
And with her fled away without abode.
For being fled into the fishers bote,
Like as a fearefull Partridge, that is fled
(Said he,) out of the flames for safegard fled,
He fled for feare of that he had misdonne,
